title: Product Market Fit
description: You've been iterating on your product for months. Your latest version seems to be gaining traction.

choices.resultText: You optimize your onboarding funnel and see a significant increase in conversion rates. Your user base grows steadily.
You build out new features that some power users love, but the overall growth is modest. The product becomes more complex.
The research reveals critical insights about your users. You make targeted changes that dramatically improve adoption and retention.

title: Pricing Strategy
description: Your product has proven value, but you're not sure how to price it. The decision could significantly impact your growth and revenue.

choices.resultText: Your user base grows rapidly, but only a small percentage converts to paid. You have a lot of users but modest revenue.
You attract fewer but higher-quality customers. Your revenue per user is excellent, though growth is slower.
You create multiple price points for different customer segments. It's more complex to manage, but provides the best balance of growth and revenue.

title: Key Employee Departure
description: Your first engineering hire, who knows the codebase better than anyone, has received an offer from a FAANG company.

choices.resultText: They accept your offer and stay, but it creates some tension with other employees who learn about the special treatment.
You wish them well and organize a proper knowledge transfer. Development slows down, but you gain deeper technical understanding yourself.
You offer remote work and flexible hours. They stay, and you establish a new company policy that improves overall team satisfaction while reducing office costs.

title: Scaling Challenges
description: Your user base is growing rapidly, and your infrastructure is struggling to keep up.

choices.resultText: The new hire rebuilds your infrastructure with scalability in mind. Your system now handles traffic spikes smoothly.

choices.text: Move to a managed cloud solution
choices.resultText: You pay more for hosting, but gain reliability without hiring specialist staff. It's a good middle ground solution.
You personally lead a rewrite of the bottleneck components. It takes time and energy, but the result is a highly optimized system that can handle 10x the load.

title: Marketing Channel Breakthrough
description: After experimenting with various marketing channels, one seems to be performing exceptionally well.

choices.text: Double down on the successful channel
choices.resultText: You increase spending on the successful channel and see proportional growth in users and revenue.
You maintain the successful channel while testing others. Growth is steady, and you reduce the risk of depending on a single acquisition source.
The specialist optimizes your marketing efforts and takes over campaign management, freeing up your time while delivering strong results.

title: Competitor Response
description: A well-funded competitor has noticed your success and launched a similar product with aggressive pricing.

choices.resultText: You maintain market share but at the cost of your margins. The price war hurts your bottom line.
You accelerate your roadmap to build features they don't have. Users appreciate the unique value, though it requires intense work.
To your surprise, they're interested in acquiring your company! After due diligence, they offer $2M for your technology and team.

title: Cash Flow Crisis
description: Despite growing users, your burn rate has outpaced revenue growth. You have only 2 months of runway left.

choices.resultText: You secure funding, but at a down-round valuation that dilutes your ownership significantly.
You lay off 30% of the team and cut all non-essential expenses. Morale plummets but your runway extends to 8 months.

choices.text: Pivot to a more profitable model
choices.resultText: You make the difficult decision to pivot toward enterprise customers. You lose many small customers but gain a few high-value contracts that solve your cash problems.

title: Security Breach
description: Your security team has discovered a major data breach. Customer data has been exposed for up to 72 hours.

choices.resultText: You face backlash and lose customers, but your transparency earns respect from industry observers and remaining users.

choices.text: Downplay the incident while fixing it
choices.resultText: The short-term impact is lessened, but tech journalists eventually uncover the full extent. Your reputation takes a lasting hit.
The professionals guide you through disclosure, remediation, and communication. The expense is significant, but damage is minimized.

title: Co-founder Conflict
description: A fundamental disagreement about the company's direction has created a rift between you and your co-founder.

choices.resultText: You negotiate a buyout that strains your cash reserves but gives you full control. The team is relieved that the conflict is over.
A professional mediator helps you find common ground. The relationship remains tense but workable, and the company can move forward.

choices.text: Propose a structured split of responsibilities
choices.resultText: Your thoughtful proposal gives each founder control over different aspects of the business. With clear boundaries, your complementary strengths begin to shine again.

title: Acquisition Offer
description: A major player in your industry has approached you with an acquisition offer of $20M.

choices.resultText: You accept the offer and successfully exit your startup. Your team is excited about joining the larger company, and you secure a good outcome for your investors.
You make a compelling case based on your growth and revenue. After negotiations, they increase their offer to $30M. Your investors are thrilled with the outcome.
You believe your company has greater potential. The team is energized by your confidence in the mission, though some are disappointed about missing the exit opportunity.

title: IPO Opportunity
description: Your company has reached a scale where an IPO is feasible. Investment bankers are eager to take you public.

choices.resultText: After months of intense preparation, your company goes public at a $500M valuation. The IPO is successful, though the process was exhausting.
You raise a large private round at a $200M valuation, maintaining more control and avoiding public market scrutiny. Your investors are satisfied with the growth prospects.
You pursue both IPO preparations and acquisition talks simultaneously. The competition drives up your valuation, resulting in a $700M acquisition by a strategic buyer.

title: Coffee Shop Networking
description: While working at a coffee shop, you overhear entrepreneurs discussing their startups. One might be a potential collaborator.

choices.resultText: The conversation leads to them investing a small amount in your startup. Sometimes serendipity pays off!
You pick up valuable insights about product development and avoid common pitfalls they discuss.

title: Side Hustle Opportunity
description: A friend offers you freelance work that could bring in $5,000, but it would take time away from your startup.

choices.resultText: The money helps with personal expenses, but you lose momentum on your startup development.
You maintain focus and make significant progress on your core product features.

title: Demo Day Dress Rehearsal
description: Other founders suggest doing a practice pitch session before the real demo day. It could help, but costs time.

choices.resultText: The practice session reveals weak spots in your pitch. You fix them and deliver much better at demo day.
Solo practice helps, but you miss the valuable feedback that other founders could have provided.

title: Media Coverage Opportunity
description: A tech blogger wants to write about your startup after demo day. Great exposure, but they ask tough questions.

choices.resultText: The article brings new users and catches investor attention. The tough questions actually make you seem more credible.
You avoid potential scrutiny but miss valuable exposure. You focus on building instead.

title: Investor Follow-up Strategy
description: After demo day, you have 5 investor emails to respond to. You need to prioritize your approach.

choices.resultText: Your quick response impresses investors. One writes a check immediately for seed funding.
Tailored responses based on their portfolios lead to better conversations and higher valuations.

title: Seed Round Term Sheet
description: Your first real term sheet arrives! $500K at a $3M valuation, but with investor protection clauses.

choices.resultText: You're officially funded! The protection clauses sting, but you have runway to prove yourself.
Your negotiation skills pay off! Better valuation and fewer protective provisions.
You create a bidding war but exhaust yourself and annoy the original investor. Mixed results.

title: Accelerator Demo Day Prep
description: If you're in an accelerator, demo day is approaching. The pressure is intense and everyone's competing for attention.

choices.resultText: Investors love your data-driven approach. Your metrics tell a compelling growth story.
Your story resonates emotionally. Investors remember you even if your metrics aren't the strongest.

title: First Paying Customer
description: Someone wants to pay for your product! It's not much ($500/month), but it validates your concept.

choices.resultText: Your excitement is infectious! The news spreads and brings more early customers.
You use the validation to focus on product improvements rather than marketing.

title: User Feedback Loop
description: Early users are giving mixed feedback. Some love it, others find it confusing. How do you respond?

choices.resultText: Doubling down on what works leads to strong word-of-mouth growth from satisfied customers.
Improving usability broadens your market appeal, though growth is slower initially.

title: Pricing Experiment
description: You need to test different pricing models. Your current price might be too low or too high.

choices.resultText: Higher prices filter out casual users but dramatically increase revenue per customer.
Tiered pricing captures more value from power users while keeping basic plans accessible.

title: Team Building Decision
description: You need help but can't afford senior talent. Should you hire junior developers or find co-founders?

choices.resultText: Junior developers are affordable but need training. Progress is slower but costs are manageable.
A new co-founder brings expertise and shares the workload, accelerating development significantly.

title: Growth Hacking Discovery
description: You discover a growth channel that's working well. Should you exploit it heavily or diversify?

choices.resultText: Massive growth through this single channel, but you're vulnerable if it stops working.
More sustainable growth across multiple channels, though it requires more resources.

title: Competitor Acquisition Offer
description: A larger competitor offers to acquire you for $2M. It's earlier than you hoped, but it's real money.

choices.resultText: You take the exit and join the larger company. Not the unicorn dream, but financial security achieved!
You bet on yourself and keep building. The validation boosts confidence, but you wonder what could have been.

title: Series A Preparation
description: VCs are sniffing around for your Series A. You need strong metrics and a compelling growth story.

choices.resultText: Strong revenue growth impresses investors and validates your business model clearly.
Rapid user growth shows market demand, though monetization questions remain.

title: Cash Flow Crisis
description: Despite growth, you're burning cash faster than expected. Runway is down to 8 weeks.

choices.resultText: You raise bridge funding but at terrible terms. Desperation shows and investors extract harsh conditions.
Severe cuts extend runway but devastate team morale and slow progress significantly.
Aggressive sales efforts bring in cash quickly. Not sustainable long-term, but saves the company.

title: Key Customer Threatens to Leave
description: Your biggest customer (40% of revenue) is unhappy and considering switching to a competitor.

choices.resultText: You keep them but at a much lower price. Revenue drops but the relationship survives.
Losing them hurts, but you build a more diverse customer base that's less risky.

title: Technical Debt Crisis
description: Your rapid growth has created massive technical debt. The system is becoming unstable.

choices.resultText: A month of rebuilding creates a solid foundation, but you lose momentum and some users.
Quick fixes keep things running, but technical debt continues to accumulate dangerously.

title: IPO vs Acquisition Decision
description: You have two exit options: a $50M acquisition offer or preparing for an IPO that could be worth $200M+.

choices.resultText: You take the certain money and achieve a great outcome for everyone involved.
You begin the grueling IPO process. High risk, high reward - but the stress is immense.

title: IPO Success
description: Your IPO is successful! The company goes public at a $150M valuation.

choices.resultText: You've achieved the ultimate startup dream! Your company is public and you're worth tens of millions.

title: Legacy Decision
description: As a successful founder, you're considering what to do next. Angel investing, starting another company, or taking a break?

result.gameOverReason: Successful exit - now helping other founders as an angel investor

choices.resultText: You use your experience and wealth to help the next generation of entrepreneurs succeed.

result.gameOverReason: Serial entrepreneur - starting your next venture!

choices.resultText: The startup bug has bitten hard. You're already planning your next big venture with hard-earned wisdom.
